File and Directory Management (15 Commands)

  1. ls - List directory contents (ls -la for detailed view with hidden files).
  2. cd - Change directory (cd ~/projects to navigate to your GitHub project folder).
  3. pwd - Print working directory (useful for scripting or verifying paths).
  4. mkdir - Create directories (mkdir -p src/main/java for nested project structures).
  5. rm - Remove files or directories (rm -rf temp/ for recursive deletion).
  6. cp - Copy files/directories (cp -r src/ backup/ for project backups).
  7. mv - Move/rename files (mv old.java new.java for refactoring).
  8. touch - Create empty files (touch script.sh for new scripts).
  9. find - Search for files (find / -name "*.java" to locate source files).
  10. locate - Quickly find files by name (locate config.yaml for configs).
  11. du - Estimate disk usage (du -sh /var/log to check log sizes).
  12. df - Display disk space (df -h for human-readable format).
  13. ln - Create links (ln -s /path/to/project symlink for shortcuts).
  14. chmod - Change file permissions (chmod 755 script.sh for executable scripts).
  15. chown - Change file ownership (chown user:group file for deployment).

Text Processing and Manipulation (15 Commands)

  1. cat - Display file contents (cat log.txt for quick log checks).
  2. less - View files interactively (less server.log for large logs).
  3. more - Paginate file output (more README.md for documentation).
  4. head - Show first lines of a file (head -n 10 data.csv for data previews).
  5. tail - Show last lines (tail -f app.log for real-time log monitoring).
  6. grep - Search text patterns (grep -r "error" /var/log for debugging).
  7. awk - Process text columns (awk '{print $1}' access.log for log parsing).
  8. sed - Stream editor for text (sed 's/old/new/g' file for replacements).
  9. cut - Extract sections from lines (cut -d',' -f1 data.csv for CSVs).
  10. sort - Sort lines (sort -n data.txt for numerical sorting).
  11. uniq - Remove duplicate lines (sort file | uniq for unique entries).
  12. wc - Count lines, words, or characters (wc -l code.java for line count).
  13. tr - Translate characters (tr '[:lower:]' '[:upper:]' < file for case conversion).
  14. tee - Write to file and stdout (cat input | tee output.txt for logging).
  15. diff - Compare files (diff old.java new.java for code changes).

System Monitoring and Performance (15 Commands)

  1. top - Monitor system processes interactively (real-time CPU/memory usage).
  2. htop - Enhanced process viewer (htop for better visualization).
  3. ps - List processes (ps aux | grep java for Java apps).
  4. free - Check memory usage (free -m for MB format).
  5. vmstat - Virtual memory stats (vmstat 1 for continuous updates).
  6. iostat - Monitor I/O performance (iostat -x for disk stats).
  7. uptime - Show system uptime and load (uptime for quick checks).
  8. lscpu - Display CPU info (lscpu for system specs).
  9. lsblk - List block devices (lsblk for disk/partition details).
  10. iotop - Monitor disk I/O by process (iotop for performance debugging).
  11. netstat - Network statistics (netstat -tuln for listening ports).
  12. ss - Modern replacement for netstat (ss -tuln for sockets).
  13. dmesg - View kernel messages (dmesg | grep error for system issues).
  14. sar - Collect system activity (sar -u 1 for CPU monitoring).
  15. pmap - Process memory map (pmap -x <pid> for memory debugging).

Networking and Connectivity (15 Commands)

  1. ping - Test network connectivity (ping google.com for reachability).
  2. curl - Fetch data from URLs (curl -X POST api for API testing).
  3. wget - Download files (wget file.tar.gz for project dependencies).
  4. netcat - Network utility (nc -l 12345 for simple servers).
  5. ifconfig - Network interface info (ifconfig eth0 for IP details).
  6. ip - Modern network config (ip addr for interface details).
  7. nslookup - Query DNS (nslookup domain.com for DNS debugging).
  8. dig - Detailed DNS lookup (dig domain.com for DNS records).
  9. traceroute - Trace network path (traceroute google.com for routing).
  10. telnet - Test port connectivity (telnet localhost 8080 for services).
  11. scp - Securely copy files (scp file user@server:/path for transfers).
  12. rsync - Sync files efficiently (rsync -avz src/ dest/ for backups).
  13. ufw - Manage firewall (ufw allow 80 for web server access).
  14. iptables - Configure firewall rules (iptables -L for rules list).
  15. nmap - Network scanning (nmap localhost for open ports).

Development and Scripting (15 Commands)

  1. gcc - Compile C programs (gcc -o app code.c for building).
  2. javac - Compile Java code (javac Main.java for your Java projects).
  3. java - Run Java programs (java -jar app.jar for execution).
  4. python3 - Run Python scripts (python3 script.py for ML tasks).
  5. node - Run Node.js (node app.js for JavaScript projects).
  6. npm - Manage Node packages (npm install for frontend deps).
  7. git - Version control (git commit -m "update" for your GitHub repos).
  8. make - Build projects (make -f Makefile for automation).
  9. mvn - Maven build tool (mvn package for Java projects).
  10. gradle - Gradle build tool (gradle build for Android projects).
  11. docker - Manage containers (docker run -p 8080:8080 app for deployments).
  12. kubectl - Manage Kubernetes (kubectl get pods for cluster management).
  13. virtualenv - Python virtual environments (virtualenv venv for ML).
  14. gdb - Debug programs (gdb ./app for C/Java debugging).
  15. strace - Trace system calls (strace -p <pid> for debugging).

Package Management (10 Commands)

  1. apt - Package manager (apt install vim for software installation).
  2. apt-get - Advanced package tool (apt-get upgrade for system updates).
  3. dpkg - Manage .deb packages (dpkg -i package.deb for manual installs).
  4. apt-cache - Query package info (apt-cache search java for packages).
  5. snap - Manage snap packages (snap install code for VS Code).
  6. update-alternatives - Manage default apps (update-alternatives --config java).
  7. add-apt-repository - Add PPAs (add-apt-repository ppa:repo for sources).
  8. apt-file - Find package files (apt-file search /bin/bash for debugging).
  9. dpkg-query - Query installed packages (dpkg-query -l for list).
  10. apt-mark - Mark packages (apt-mark hold package to prevent upgrades).

System Administration and Security (15 Commands)

  1. sudo - Run commands as root (sudo apt update for admin tasks).
  2. su - Switch user (su - user for different accounts).
  3. passwd - Change passwords (passwd user for security).
  4. useradd - Add user (useradd -m dev for new accounts).
  5. usermod - Modify user (usermod -aG sudo dev for permissions).
  6. groupadd - Create groups (groupadd developers for access control).
  7. chgrp - Change group ownership (chgrp -R dev /project for teams).
  8. crontab - Schedule tasks (crontab -e for automated scripts).
  9. systemctl - Manage services (systemctl start nginx for web servers).
  10. journalctl - View system logs (journalctl -u docker for service logs).
  11. who - List logged-in users (who for server monitoring).
  12. last - Show login history (last for security audits).
  13. shutdown - Power off (shutdown -h now for system halt).
  14. reboot - Restart system (reboot for updates).
  15. env - Display environment variables (env | grep PATH for debugging).

Notes for Your Context

  • Development Focus: Commands like git, mvn, docker, and kubectl align with your full-stack and containerized workflows, especially for your 10 GitHub projects and cloud experience (AWS, Azure, Alibaba Cloud).
  • Debugging and Performance: Tools like strace, gdb, htop, and dmesg are included for your backend and system debugging needs, given your 8 years of backend experience.
  • Networking: Commands like curl, netcat, and nmap support your API and networking expertise, useful for testing microservices or cloud deployments.
  • Automation: crontab and rsync are handy for automating backups or deployments, relevant to your freelance and corporate roles.
  • Research and Learning: Text processing tools (grep, awk, sed) are useful for parsing logs or datasets, which could support your self-taught research on vision restoration.
